content: There is only one example provided and it's hard to tell what the objective is. Definitely a fun challenge and I would approve more examples were provided (outside of test cases)
In the "reverse" mode, all you get to see is the test cases. That's kinda the point of it.

I specifically mean that more of the tests should be part of the actual statement. the "jump" test would be good one imo. Otherwise it's a bit hard to figure out what the goal is, especially considering it's not really that simple of a goal (compared to most other reverses i've seen).

In "reverse", you only get to see the test cases, you don't see the statement!

--> This clashes with "I specifically mean that more of the tests should be part of the actual statement"

I don't know how to explain it any better, an example is an example. 
Only one of the test cases is given as an example, it would be better if more of them were given as examples, i am aware that you can manually see the examples by printing and testing manually but that takes long.

"Reverse mode" puzzles start with the following text:

[The game mode is REVERSE: You do not have access to the statement. You have to guess what to do by observing the following set of tests:]

--> In reverse, you can't see the statement (or example) section!
--> The tests are the example! 

Take note next time you run into a reverse mode puzzle.
It would be very cool if you could stop being condescending simply because you cannot understand what I am saying.

In reverse mode, there are specific examples that the creator provides, that are hand-picked from the tests in order to provide a good idea of what the program is meant to do. 

In this problem, if you bothered to open the IDE, there is only one example, out of the many tests. 

I am simply saying that there should be more than 1 example for a problem as complex as this.

And as i said before, 
> I am aware that you can manually see the examples by printing and testing manually but that takes time.

Firstly, Sorry if that "sounded" condescending, that wasn't the aim at all.

Yes, I did bother to open the IDE and was able to solve the task w/o issues.

The IDE in the clash verification mode looks much what it looks like in "fastest" or "shortest" mode --> Only first test case is shown

If you start a clash in "reverse" mode, then instead of statement and explanation and such, you see the test cases, I mean, all of them in their full glory (of course not the verification ones)

--> You will see <<all four (!) test cases at once>> when the puzzle is started <<in reverse mode>>
--> In reverse mode, you do not have to check the test cases manually, they are presented right from the beginning
--> In reverse mode, you will see no statement, description, examples etc.

Take note next time you run into a reverse mode puzzle ... in a real-life-clash

Perhaps you're right, I've seen other reverses where they've had only one example but multiple tests and i assumed this is why. 
This is my first contribution so i assumed that the example they provided would be the only one given, if what you're saying is true then I guess i'm mistaken.

I actually went out, played a few clashes until I encountered a reverse one, took note of how they're displayed and came back to give my third input above (observe how I copy-pasted the intro text in that response).

I'm surprised that you say you saw an example in your reverse mode encounter, because all I saw last time around were the test cases
